column1: All of the following answers are true EXCEPT: The glycocalyx is composed of:
column8: The glycocalyx is a carbohydrate-rich surface coat. It is composed of glycolipids, glycoproteins, and proteoglycans. Lipoproteins are plasma transport particles and are not structural components of the cell surface.

column1: Which cytoskeleton is associated with the focal adhesion:
column8: Focal adhesions connect the extracellular matrix to the actin cytoskeleton via integrins and adaptor proteins such as talin and vinculin. They are involved in cell migration and mechanotransduction.

column1: All of the following statements regarding hematoxylin & eosin (H&E) stain are true EXCEPT:
column2: Hematoxylin is a basic stain, eosin is an acidic stain
column4: Basophilic structures are red in color
column8: Basophilic structures bind hematoxylin and appear blue or purple. Red or pink staining is characteristic of eosinophilic (acidophilic) structures.

column1: The approximate size of the platelets is:
column8: Platelets are small anucleate cytoplasmic fragments derived from megakaryocytes. Their diameter is approximately 2–4 µm, smaller than erythrocytes.

column1: Retrograde axonal transport is executed by the protein:
column8: Dynein mediates retrograde transport along microtubules toward the neuronal cell body. Kinesin mediates anterograde transport.

column1: Which of the following is typical for inhibitory synapses?
column2: Both pre- and postsynaptic membranes are with a similar thickness
column8: Inhibitory synapses (Gray type II) are symmetric, with similar thickness of pre- and postsynaptic membranes, and typically cause hyperpolarization.

column1: Which one of the following statements is NOT true regarding loose connective tissue?
column2: The cells are arranged in isogenous groups
column3: It builds lamina propria of mucous membranes
column4: It is the site of first contact between bacteria and immune system
column5: Most of the cell types are temporary migrating cells
column6: It can increase substantially its volume during swelling
column8: Isogenous cell groups are characteristic of cartilage. Loose connective tissue contains dispersed cells, abundant ground substance, and plays a role in immune defense and edema.

column1: When does implantation after fertilization end?
column8: Implantation begins around day 6–7 and is completed by day 10 after fertilization, when the conceptus is fully embedded in the endometrium.

column1: Which of the statements regarding the types of spermatogonia is NOT true?
column6: Type C – stem cell generating Sertoli cells
column8: Sertoli cells are somatic supporting cells derived embryologically and not from spermatogonia. Type C spermatogonia do not exist in standard classification.

column1: Which effect have prostaglandins of the semen?
column2: They reduce viscosity of cervical mucus
column4: They stimulate peristaltic contractions of female tract
column8: Seminal prostaglandins reduce cervical mucus viscosity and stimulate uterine and tubal smooth muscle contractions, facilitating sperm transport.

column1: Which embryonic layer is in direct contact with the parietal hypoblast until formation of extraembryonic mesoderm?
column6: None of the answers is true
column8: Before formation of extraembryonic mesoderm, the parietal hypoblast (Heuser’s membrane) is directly apposed to the cytotrophoblast.

column1: Which of the following statement IS TRUE?
column2: Chorionic villi form the fetal part of the placenta
column3: Chorionic villi do not form the fetal part
column4: Chorionic villi form the maternal part
column5: Chorionic villi form the entire placenta
column8: The placenta consists of a fetal part (chorion frondosum with chorionic villi) and a maternal part (decidua basalis).

column1: In the beginning of the 3rd week the paraxial mesoderm differentiates into segments known as:
column8: The paraxial mesoderm segments into somites at the beginning of the third week, giving rise to sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.

column1: Which cytoskeleton is associated with the adherent (adherens) junction?
column8: Adherens junctions (zonula adherens) connect actin filaments of adjacent cells via cadherins and catenins, providing mechanical linkage and signaling.

column1: Match the tissue to its characteristic location: Dense irregular connective tissue =>
column8: Dense irregular connective tissue is typical for the deep (reticular) layer of the dermis, where collagen bundles are arranged in multiple directions to resist stress.

column1: Match the tissue to its characteristic location: Elastic connective tissue =>
column8: Elastic connective tissue is rich in elastic fibers and is classically found in elastic ligaments such as ligamenta flava (ligg. flava).

column1: Match the tissue to its characteristic location: Bone tissue =>
column8: Bone is mineralized connective tissue forming the skeleton.

column1: Match the tissue to its characteristic location: Reticular connective tissue =>
column8: Reticular connective tissue (type III collagen network) forms the supportive stroma of lymphoid organs such as the spleen.

column1: Match the tissue to its characteristic location: Mucous connective tissue =>
column8: Mucous connective tissue (Wharton’s jelly) is characteristic of the umbilical cord, with abundant ground substance and sparse fibers.
